pr_title: fix(iot-dev): Fix issue where amqp layer ignored delivery state of sent messages

timeline.message: fix(iot-dev): Fix issue where amqp layer ignored delivery state of sent messages

timeline.bodyText: The exception translator above does the hard work of figuring out if the message can be retried or not
timeline.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Does the service ever send a delivery state of "released"? What do they expect the client to do, in this case?
timeline.author: abhipsaMisra

replies.bodyText: I've never seen it, but the protocol defines it as a possible delivery state. As a delivery state, it just means that the service has made the message available to be re-delivered for whatever reason. So on the client side, we just need to create a retryable exception here so that the transport layer re-sends it
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText:
why is the check for rejected look different than the other delivery states?
Shouldn't it be
deliveryState == Rejected.getInstance() ?
timeline.author: azabbasi

replies.bodyText: Rejected is the one delivery state that comes with additional information in the ack. For Accepted/Released, there is no payload telling why the message was Accepted/Released. For Rejected, there should be some error details explaining why the message was rejected
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: There are at least 4 more delivery state types that are defined in the transport layer that will fall into the else statement here, can you point me to the service documentation that indicates what delivery states they may return? I am just curious.
timeline.author: azabbasi

replies.bodyText: There isn't any documentation like that, unfortunately. For Modified/Received, I'm not sure what the SDK is supposed to do. I've never seen those delivery states returned, though
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText:
From the official AMQP spec, though:
• accepted: indicates successful processing at the receiver.
• rejected: indicates an invalid and unprocessable message.
• released: indicates that the message was not (and will not be) processed.
• modified: indicates that the message was modified, but not processed.
• received: indicates partial message data seen by the receiver as well as the starting point for a resumed transfer.
replies.author: timtay-microsoft
